title: Instant and Duration subscriptions for `crux_time`
body:
Updates `crux_time` capability to be more closely aligned with [`wasi-clocks`](https://github.com/WebAssembly/wasi-clocks/).

- [x] update `now` to return an `Instant`, which represents a UTC point in time (number of seconds since the epoch and number of nanoseconds since the last second).
- [x] add `subscribe_duration` and its async counterpart. The shell side of the capability responds when the requested duration has elapsed.
- [x] add `subscribe_instant` and its async counterpart. The shell side of the capability responds when the requested instant has arrived.
- [x] Add a test that demonstrates a debounce based on `subscribe_duration`

title: update all deps and dioxus examples
body:
- [x] update rust deps
- [x] update pnpm deps
- [x] update `dioxus` examples (`counter` and `simple_counter` to 0.5 with signals)

title: Clarifications to capability runtime docs
body: @charypar nice job on these docs! I think they are clear and comprehensive. Here are a few suggestions for clarification, from an end-user perspective.

title: Docs: Suggestions from following the Getting Started guide
body:
I've added a few pointers for things I got stuck on or had to check when following the 'Getting Started' guide in the book.

Some of these will be helpful for Rust devs that aren't that familiar with app development, and others hopefully avoid getting stuck where there's sensitivity to exact naming or setup.

title: docs: fix typo
body: “it’s” is a contraction of “it is”.

title: docs: fix typo
body: “who’s” is a contraction of “who is”. It should be “whose”.

title: fix a link error in README
body: I just heard of this project on YouTube. What a great idea! I am studying it now

title: Update examples for latest `crux_http`
body:
- [x] update crate deps
- [x] expose `HttpErrorHttp` from `crux_http`
- [x] add `impl From<Result<HttpResponse, HttpError>> for HttpResult` to `crux_http`
- [x] update all variants of `counter` and `cat_facts` examples to use `HttpResult`
- [x] move `cli` and `tauri` examples from `surf` to `reqwest` (`surf` now requires silly conversions since we started using a fork of `http-types` in `crux_http`)
- [x] move from `async-std` to `tokio`

title: Update link to rust file in hello_world.md

body: Update Counter example to use newly published `crux_http` 0.8

title: chore: bump crux_http version to 0.8.0
body:
- Updates the version of crux_http from 0.7.0 to 0.8.0
- Fixes a type generation problem with the newly exposed `HttpResult` and `HttpError`

title: Update book getting started guide to fix links and cargo toml examples
body:
Fixes #210 

Some of the links in the getting started guide for the shared (and shared types) libraries were pointing to the `counter` example instead of the `simple_counter` example, which was confusing. 
Also the workspace `Cargo.toml` were incorrect if you are following along as it had workspace members that don't exist yet.

title: Release crux_http 0.7.1
body:
### Changes

- Fixes a type generation problem with the newly exposed `HttpResult` and `HttpError`
- **Requires explicit tracing of crux_http::HttpError when using typegen**

title: Update counter example to latest crux_core and crux_http.
body:
This is work in progress for now, once we release #207 I'll bump to the newly rleased version of `crux_http` and merge

- [x] update to latest crux_http API
- [x] add missing type tracing  
- [x] use crates rather than local paths

title: crux_http: Restrict exported error variants
body:
This avoids a type generation problem due to custom deserializer on `http::StatusCode`. 

The change also makes semantic sense - the shell-side of the capability should not be generating HTTP errors and JSON errors anyway, as that is done by the core side of it.

Even with this change, the type tracing is no longer able to find all the relevant types, and an additional line is required in the `build.rs` file in `shared_types`:

```rust
gen.register_type::<HttpError>()?;
```

title: Release crux_http 0.7.0
body:
New version of crux_http

## Breaking changes

- **The protocol between shell and core has changed. Core now expects a `HttpResult` rather than a `HttpResponse`**, see #204 for details

title: crux_http: Allow non-HTTP errors to be represented by shell
body: Introduce `HttpResult` to the shell protocol, to allow the shell to signal an error other than a HTTP error - currently these are IO and Timeout (there may be more to come).

title: Better error handling for crux_http
body:
This should allow apps to handle HTTP errors better and provide special error handling for bad requests, unauthorized requests and other common situations that can be handled gracefully.

There are two changes
* A nicer error type which is easier to work with
* When using the event returning API, response status in the 4xx and 5xx range is considered an `Err` not an `Ok`

title: add display implementation for crux_http::error::Error
body: fixes: #190

title: update examples to latest crux
body: This PR updates all the examples to work with the latest versions of crux crates. I also moved the crux dependencies to become workspace dependencies so that they are in sync and easy to point to local paths when testing.

title: `crux_http` to use form of `http-types`
body:
The published `http-types` crate uses 128bit `trace_id`, which doesn't compile for `wasm32-unknown-emscripten`.

See https://github.com/http-rs/http-types/pull/522

title: Allow bridge to use different serializer
body:
Addresses #191. The current state is pretty awful and not ready to ship, but the basic mechanics should work, I hope.

# to do
- [x] Proof of concept implementation
- [x] Test examples across platforms for backwards compatibility
- [x] Add a test with JSON serialization
- [x] Choose better names for things
- [x] Document, and add warnings about typegen not supporting other serialization than bincode (at least for now)

title: remove http_types default features from crux_http
body: The `crux_http` capability crate depended on the `http_types` feature `fs`, which does not compile for `wasm32-unknown-emscripten`. This PR removes that and the code that depended on it (which doesn't make sense inside a Crux core anyway).

I'm aiming to cover the capability runtime, Operations, Requests, and the serialisation in the bridge. The Effect derive macro and typegen are probably a separate docs PR.

title: Async KV and Time capability APIs
body:
Resolves #181 and #182.

Updates both KV and Time capbilities adding an async version of their API. I also switched the Time capability to use Chrono for the underlying representation - it supports timezones and serialization, so it was quite an easy choice. Open to suggestions for a better choice, if you think Chrono is too heavy a dependency for this. 

I also made `Render` capability `Clone` so it can be used along async composition (otherwise typical `Capabilities` can't be `Clone`).

title: Update capability orchestration docs to use working code
body: I've tested this inside the integration test, but didn't commit that change. Can do if you'd like.

title: Add async API to crux_http
body: Resolves #180.

title: Async capability combinators
body:
This PR is work in progress on #91.

It turns out, surprisingly, that async capability combinators were always possible in "user land", and could be implemented as an additional capability, but the implementation is not exactly obvious, and this type of use needs to be supported by the capabilities being orchestrated across, especially `crux_http`.

This PR aims to make the use of `async` across multiple capabilities more obvious. There are a few challenges to overcome

- [x] The Orchestrate capability should probably come with crux_core
- [ ] ~Automatically derive `Clone` for capabilities and the `Capabilities` struct, to avoid various lifetime errors when moving the capabilities or the context into the async blocks~  - decided against, it would conflict with custom `Clone` implementations
- [x] Provide a `Never` operation type
- [x] Avoid producing an `Effect` variant for capabilities who's ~operations are `Never` ()~ fields are `#[effect(skip)]`
- [x] The use needs thorough documentation and an example
- [ ] Existing capabilities need to expose an async version of their APIs (#180, #181, #182)

All feedback on the ergonomics of this is welcome at this stage, but I'd like to aim to ship this soon, ideally this week.

title: remove uuid unused wasm-bindgen feature flag
body:
`uuid` 1.7.0 has dropped the wasm-bindgen feature flag making it incompatible with previous versions (<= 1.6.1). 

The response from `uuid` maintainers:

> Thanks for pointing this out! The `wasm-bindgen` dependency was never meant to be public. It was only a Cargo limitation that made it so. Packages should instead use the js feature...

title: Improve typegen error handling
body:
Fixes #161 

Improves error handling during typegen and adds `TypeGenError::PnpmNotFound` in order to catch the more common error of not having `pnpm` installed. The error now looks like this:

```
cargo build
   Compiling shared_types v0.1.0 (/Users/stuartharris/src/redbadger/crux/examples/simple_counter/shared_types)
error: failed to run custom build command for `shared_types v0.1.0 (/Users/stuartharris/src/redbadger/crux/examples/simple_counter/shared_types)`

Caused by:
  process didn't exit successfully: `/Users/stuartharris/src/redbadger/crux/examples/simple_counter/target/debug/build/shared_types-8703d4b47d26cc47/build-script-build` (exit status: 1)
  --- stdout
  cargo:rerun-if-changed=../shared

  --- stderr
  Error: `pnpm` is needed for TypeScript type generation, but it could not be found in PATH.
  Please install it from https://pnpm.io/installation

  Caused by:
      No such file or directory (os error 2)
```

title: Local install of cargo-xcode@1.7.0
body:
Recent changes to `cargo-xcode` mean that we need to use version <=1.7.0 for now. We are investigating why this is (and also looking for alternatives).

In the meantime, installing `cargo-xcode` globally can be problematic (tools such as [`topgrade`](https://github.com/topgrade-rs/topgrade) will keep updating it). Fortunately, `cargo-run-bin` allows us to use an install of `cargo-xcode` that is local to our repo. I have updated the example `Cargo.toml` files to include the locked version, and updated the book documentation to describe how to set up `cargo-xcode` both globally and locally.

body:
- [x] update Rust dependencies
- [x] update iOS dependencies
- [x] update Android dependencies
- [x] update NextJS dependencies
- [x] update Remix dependencies

title: Added Send trait to NewEv generic type inside Capability derive macro
Leptos 0.5.0
body:
In Leptos 0.5.0, components no longer need context (`cx: Scope`), which simplifies our examples. This PR updates  our examples accordingly.

Also updates Yew to 0.21, Tauri to 1.5, `toml`, `thiserror`, and `insta` — all of which AFAICT have no breaking changes.

title: Generated java types general housekeeping
body: When building the core app with an android target, java files are generated that we reference from kotlin to help facilitate our interaction with the core app. During this process, any types that were no longer being used were left in place. This PR updates the Java type generation helper clean up the shared types directory before generating the updated set of types.

title: extract core in android examples
body:
- [x] extract `Core` into separate file for each example
- [x] update docs

title: iOS examples — extract core wrapper
body: This updates all 6 iOS examples to extract a "core" wrapper (the generic code that only changes when new capabilities are used) and to be more consistent with each other.

title: Android improved documentation
body:
This PR improves documentation for Android and includes changes necessary to target all android devices supported by Mozilla's gradle plugin.

I have made changes to the android shared module's build.gradle in the template app; as well as, the relevant sample apps.

I have included instructions on the Android getting started covering the need to include the required rust toolchains and reflected the expected directory changes in the getting started guide.

title: Add an example that tests the bridge performance
body: ... by sending a message into the core as often as possible and rendering the UI in response, across platforms.

title: Refactor examples
body:
A bit of a large PR, sorry. This is all around tidying up the examples ahead of Rust Global in Seattle. Covers all the web-based examples, iOS and Android to follow.

- [x] update `crux doctor` to take a `path` arg so that you can see diffs just for the specified directory
- [x] make `typegen` for `cores` in `Crux.toml` optional (caters for the situation where you have `shared` but not `shared_types` (like `hello_world`)
- [x] update the examples so that all the boilerplate code is in separate files (still to do in another PR — iOS, Android, Tauri)
- [x] make the platform sub-app in catfacts a little more self contained with ability to test at sub-app level

title: Split simple counter out of hello world example
body: This PR splits the current "hello world" example into "hello world" and "simple counter"

title: Add a tap to pay example app
body: Add a demo of a simple application with a multi-screen navigation behaviour.

title: Basic `crux doctor`
body:
Basic `crux doctor`command.

- [x] `Crux.toml` — Parse, validate, rewrite
- [x] List missing files (for which there is a template)
- [x] Show diffs between existing files and their rendered templates
- [x] Add embryonic templates for cores and shells

contributes to #126 

```bash
Usage: crux [OPTIONS] --template-dir <TEMPLATE_DIR> [COMMAND]

Commands:
  doctor  [aliases: doc]
  help    Print this message or the help of the given subcommand(s)

Options:
  -t, --template-dir <TEMPLATE_DIR>  temporary
  -v, --verbose...
  -i, --include-source-code
  -h, --help                         Print help
  -V, --version                      Print version
```

e.g, this gives the all clear...

```bash
cd examples/simple_counter
crux -t ../../templates/simple_counter doctor
```

... but this would show up some diffs
```bash
cd examples/hello_world
crux -t ../../templates/simple_counter doctor
```

We need to work out what the templates should be and how they are distributed, but this is very much a super-minimal start

- [x] Updates the examples to be more consistent with each other. 
- [x] Re-creates all the NextJS examples, removing the use of the wasm-pack plugin (no need for it as we can now just add the `shared` and `shared_types` as packages with `pnpm`). 
- [x] Add Remix to the Counter example
- [x] Updates deps
- [x] Updates the docs to reflect the changes.

title: Fix some ignored doc tests
body: Make some more of the doc test examples compile

title: overhaul examples
body:
This PR improves our examples. 

- [x] for Android examples, don't delete (and then copy) generated types, instead use `sourceSets`
- [x] update dependencies (Rust, Kotlin and TypeScript)
- [x] improve, simplify, tidy up and refactor the shells and the cores, bringing them more in line with each other
- [x] extract out shell-side capability implementations, where they haven't already been done
- [x] remove superfluous code that was confusing
- [x] update tauri app so that start watch is instigated by the page (so we don't miss the render)

title: Add Remix to hello-world example
body:
Remix is becoming ever more popular (for good reason IMO). So I added an example Remix shell to the Hello World example.

In many ways it is very similar to the Next.js example (Remix is React after all), but there are a few tricks that are needed to bundle and load the Wasm binary. So I added a page to the docs to help with this.

title: Add response headers to HTTP Capability protocol
body:
Adds ability to use HTTP headers returned from requests. 

- [x] Add headers to `HttpResponse`
- [x] Add builder pattern to avoid having to add `..Default::default()` everywhere

title: fix cat facts example
body:
- [x] add a GET route to the Counter example server (https://crux-counter.fly.dev/cat) to replace the probably defunct API we were using. Returns a URL for a cat image randomly from a list of 25
- [x] tidy up examples

title: android flamingo
body: Update Android examples to Flamingo, Gradle 8, etc

title: Change uniffi UDL interface from `sequence<u8>` to `bytes`
body:
The [latest version of uniffi](https://github.com/mozilla/uniffi-rs/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md) introduces a [new `bytes` type](https://github.com/mozilla/uniffi-rs/pull/1543) in the `udl`, which _might_ improve our shell code for interfacing with the core.

The Kotlin code is better (means we don't need to constantly convert between various byte collection types) but the Swift code is worse (means we _do_ have to constantly convert between types). However, on balance, I think it's better and more idiomatic in Swift to use the Data type. I'm sure we can improve on this by generating a lot of the Swift and Kotlin client side code (both for capabilities and for the core interface).

title: Update dependencies and associated code
body:
This PR updates dependencies, some of which required code cahnges:
- [x] `uniffi` from `0.23` to `0.24.1` — this is a significant update (and we can probably take advantage of some [new features](https://github.com/mozilla/uniffi-rs/blob/main/CHANGELOG.md)). I updated and tested the Android and iOS apps and the NextJS web app.
- [x] `leptos` from  `0.3.1` to `0.4.0` — also a significant update. I adjusted the Leptos examples accordingly.

Note: I haven't updated `automerge` from `0.4.1` to `0.5.0` — this is much trickier. The [breaking changes](https://github.com/automerge/automerge/blob/main/rust/CHANGELOG.md) may be useful, require some refactoring.

title: Counter example in leptos
body: I was interested to see how Crux works with UI frameworks that are based on fine-grained reactivity. This is a basic example implemented in [Leptos](https://github.com/leptos-rs/leptos) that we can evolve/work with.

title: implement derive macro for Capability trait
body: Adds a derive macro for the `Capability` trait to the `crux_macros` crate, updates usages and docs

body: Fixes https://github.com/redbadger/crux/issues/93

title: Android - delete old generated files
body:
Fixes https://github.com/redbadger/crux/issues/108

Only tested on MacOS, but _should_ work on Windows too.

title: Improving DX for iOS setup
body: As a step towards improving the developer experience whilst getting started, this PR updates the docs on how to set up an iOS project (for use with Crux) using [XcodeGen](https://github.com/yonaskolb/XcodeGen).

title: use bincode instead of bcs
body:
Use [bincode](https://github.com/bincode-org/bincode) instead of [bcs](https://github.com/zefchain/bcs).

It seems to us that bincode is faster, more widely used, better maintained, supported by `serde_generate`, supports `f32` & `f64`, and probably a safer bet for now.

- [x] use the installer from `serde_generate` to output the serialization and deserialization code for Swift and Kotlin
- [x] wrap `SharedTypes` (including `serde` and `bincode`) in a Swift package for easier use on iOS
- [x] update all examples
- [x] update docs
- [x] remove redundant serialization dependencies from capability crates

title: Add autodiscovery for type generation
body:
It is possible for us to find all the types used by a Crux app by starting with the top-level type implementing the `App` trait and registering the `Event`, `ViewModel` and all the capability operations and their outputs. That is the total set of types which we will be sending across the FFI boundary (including all the types used within those types).

In this way we can avoid listing all the types manually and reduce the build.rs of the `shared_type` crates to a single line (and eventually hopefully remove it altogether).

# To do
- [x] Basic scanning of the App type
- [x] Macro generated walking of the Capabilities struct
- [x] Bridge machinery types (Request, EffectFfi, etc.)
- [x] Use in all examples

title: Add a typegen interface for registering a type with samples
body:
Adds a function that exposes a slightly lower-level interface than the existing `register_type()`. Fixes #102 

Before merge:

- [ ] remove `SendUuid` from the Counter app. I left that in for now as a sort of integration test, but we should remove it before merging.

title: enable windows users to build the android project
body:
Hi I played around a bit with crux and I was able to build the android example with these changes.
Maybe related to #82 altough I am not even sure what effect the toolchain file actually has?

The cli example also works. The others I have not tried yet. 
I thought I will provide this and maybe a nice discussion could emerge

title: Make event argument of Capability trait Send
body: For capabilities which return a "signal" – an event with no payload, the Event type needs to be `Send`. This adds the trait bound to the `Capability` trait` trait.

title: Surface resolve errors to Rust shells
body:
Core::resolve now returns a `Result<Vec<Effect>, ResolveError>`, so the errors don't just get swallowed.

I'm slightly on the fence about this – realistically, this is not an error that would happen occasionally at runtime, it's a design-time problem. There's also not much that can be done to handle it. It gets raised because the Shell is attempting to resolve a request that has already been resolved or never required resolving, and if it does happen, it is probably completely ok to ignore and carry on running (but needs investigating, because something is wrong with the effect handling).

This means the Shell code will be littered with somewhat unnecessary error handling. It might be better for Crux to just panic, like it does when used over the FFI bridge, and not bother the Shell code with `Result`s.

I'd love to hear your thoughts on this @obmarg, @StuartHarris.

title: Tidy up public API, make sure only intended things are public
Update docs to cover the Core API changes
body:
Updates the API docs and the book to reflect the recent changes to the Core API and splitting out the Bridge code.

While working on this, I've noticed there are a few types and methods which are `pub` and probably shouldn't be, and also a case of less than ideal error handling. I'll probably open another PR to tidy those bits up.

title: Run CI on PRs as well
body:
Add a trigger for the build workflow to also run on PRs (including forks). 

This should be safe to do, based on <https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/>

title: Add tauri version of examples/counter app
body:
This is a working version of the `counter` example app, using [Tauri 2.0.0 alpha](https://next--tauri.netlify.app/next/api/config/) with React. I'm opening this PR mainly to show that this combination works, and seems as clean as any of the other examples. This is all possible because of @charypar 's recent changes in #87. I'm not sure if we want to add this example to the repo. I realize that every example is a maintenance commitment, and we can't include everything.

Anyway, some notes:

- much of the code is lifted from other `counter` examples (e.g. cli), so it should be pretty familiar
- the UI is vanilla React, but the React component is copied from `examples/web-nextjs`
- so far I've only built this in the desktop dev environment
    - I haven't packaged the app yet
    - I've tried building iOS unsuccessfully. Tauri mobile is still in alpha, and it's pretty unstable at the moment. I just haven't had time to slog through the errors. This should be easy to update once the Tauri dependency settles down.

## Getting started

```
cd examples/counter
cargo build --package shared
cargo build --package shared_types
cd tauri
pnpm install
pnpm tauri dev
```

Edit: Corrected the `pnpm tauri dev` command that was causing an error with the missing `dist` folder

title: feat(crux_http): added HTTPRequest::body to protocol.rs
body:
Based on [this Zulip discussion](https://crux-community.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/373912-general/topic/http-capability) I added a request body to the protocol HTTPRequest.

Could not simply update the `impl From<crate::Request> for HttpRequest` as I needed an `async` context therefore I created a designated `trait ProtocolRequestBuilder`.

Please review ...

title: Assert effect macro
body:
Adds a macro to assert that an update emitted an `Effect` that matches the supplied pattern.

e.g.
```rust
assert_effect!(update, Effect::Render(_));
```

Partial implementation of #93. 

**Don't merge before  #87**

title: Update hello_world for Bridge
body: @charypar here's an update to your `direct-core-api` branch that gets the hello_world example and tests building. Might save you some busy work :)

title: use cargo-xcode in Xcode setup and examples
body:
We had a [problem](https://github.com/redbadger/crux/issues/88) with the iOS setup in Xcode, which meant that apps tried to load a dynamic library (rather than a static library) on physical devices.

This PR adjusts the documentation in the book, and the example iOS projects to use [`cargo-xcode`](https://crates.io/crates/cargo-xcode) to generate an Xcode project for our shared library that can be added as a sub-project in Xcode. This results in simpler setup and configuration, and links the static library into the app when deployed on an iPhone.

Fixes #88

title: Rename rustdoc::missing_doc_code_examples lint
body:
Just noticed these warnings in `crux_http` when running tests 😄 

warning: lint `missing_doc_code_examples` has been renamed to `rustdoc::missing_doc_code_examples`

There are still warnings that the lint is unstable, but now only half as many.

Was: warning: 12 warnings emitted
Now: warning: 6 warnings emitted

title: Separate bridge code from the core API
body:
So far, the Crux core was fused together with the serialisation code supporting the FFI. This PR makes changes to separate the serialisation code into a self-contained Bridge, which will handle

* Serialising and deserialising data for the FFI
* Parking the effects emitted by the app under a UUID so they can be resolved later once the Shell is done.

The key changes in this are in how `Effects`, `Steps`,  and `Operations` stack up. Previously, Steps contained Effects, which contained Operations. That meant that Steps did not have access to Operation type information and had to work on serialised bytes. By swapping the order, Steps are now generic over Operations and Effect bundle them into an enum for the purposed of dispatch. Each of the types has a specific job:

* Effect allows a type-checked dispatch in the Shell to the right capability implementation
* Step (now an enum too) captures the semantics of the interaction - is it a notification, a request with a single response, or a subscription with a stream of responses
* Operation captures the data needed to fulfil the interaction, and with the `Operation::Output` type, also the type of the result

There are a few consequences:
* Rust clients get a strongly typed API for the core with no serialisation in site 🎉 
* Capability context construction had to change because of the assymetry between a Context of Effect and Contex of Step<Operation> (not a big deal, just no introduce a different type for the initial construction and updated the macro)
* Sadly, this changes the Shell API once more. It now needs to be aware of steps. 
* This should, however, allow us to build foreign language interfaces to the core which hide the serialisation entirely, making Crux look native to them, and that API can now be the stable managed interface. This means that type generation and serialisation changes should no longer impact Shells. Or at least not as often.
* Not sure if AppTester is still necessary, it might be entirely possible to simply work with the core directly now

@obmarg I'd love to get your feedback on the work so far. I'm fairly confident this will work, but I may have missed something major.

## Updated on April 4th

There were more consequences in the end. 

* We ended up with two type sets for the bridge and the direct API. Both have an `Effect` and a `Request`, but they contain each other in a different order. Bridged effect is Request(Effect(Operation)), direct effect is Effect(Request(Operation)). This _may_ change later down to line, when we hide the UUID mechanics in the foreign language shells.
* The second Effect (called `EffectFfi` by default) is also macro generated. Original Effect now implements a trait which the bridge uses to serialize it. That turns the effect into its Ffi counterpart and a `ResolveBytes` which is an equivalent of Resolve that takes serialized output of the Operation. 
* A benefit of all this is that the foreign shell interface did not need to change 🎉 

# To do
- [x] re-stack Effect and Step
- [x] remove serialisation code
- [x] revisit construction of CapabilityContext
- [x] implement Bridge and StepRegistry for the new world
- [x] rename things to make more sense (hopefully)
- [x] organise modules in `crux_core` better
- [x] revisit AppTester and see how to make its API better for the new Effect/Request/Operation structure
- [x] update all Rust clients in examples, which now need to be ~step~ `Request` aware
